title: Stories of the Border Marches

author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: The discomforts of Humbie had been too much for both husband  and wife — they went afterwards to Auchtertool, as we have said, and Carlyle subsequently into Annandale, to his own people.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: Position between Mrs. Carlyle and Lady Ashburton — The Scotch journey  — Carlyle at ' The Gill ' — Mrs. Carlyle at Auchtertool — ' Seeking and finding ' — Sunny Bank — Tender Remembrances — The return to London — Death of Lady Ashburton — Tribute to her — Bitter reflections — Scotland again — First readings of a portion  of ' Frederick ' — Wisely pride — Mrs. Carlyle's return to Cheyne Row — Discouragement — The kindness of Mr. Henry Lar- kin— Another visit to Germany — Mrs. Carlyle at Lann Hall — Holm Hill — Letters to Mr. Larkin — Cheyne Row once more — Second marriage of Lord Ashburton — Mrs. Carlyle's thoughts of her mother — The visit to ' Humble ' and Auchtertool — Carlyle again in Annandale with his own people.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: But a lull came first, and in the summer of 1846 Mrs. Carlyle again visited her Lancashire friends, being joined by Carlyle in August after his six silent weeks in Annandale.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: A second visit from Mrs. Welsh marked the close of the lectures, and Carlyle's own departure for Annandale, in his blind desire for 'Silence ! silence ! ' The graceful and clever dialogue of ' The Bird and^the Watch ' was written for John Sterling about this time, with the pathetic ' Remonstrance of my old Watch ' — each needless to give here but for their remarkable brilliancy, and the light they cast on the character and powers of the writer.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: Mrs. Welsh decides to further the marriage — Her decision to live with her father at Templand — The Carlyle parents see the impossibility  of their son's bride living at Scotsbrig — A new home to be chosen — Impossible conditions — Blindness of Carlyle to the actual situation — Trying uncertainty— The idea of the home at Haddington as a residence for the newly-married pair — Painful objections — The idea abandoned — Recurring failure of plans — And a dissimilarity in ideas — The proposed cottage in Annandale.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: And how would it be possible not to disappoint her of this hope, if I went to reside with your people in Annandale ? . . . She would be the most wretched of mothers, the most desolate woman in the world.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: His idea at this time was to take and stock a farm in Annandale, leaving his brother Alexander to manage it.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: In May, Carlyle spent a week in Annandale, and wrote to Miss Welsh: 'Here I purpose to spend my leisure, and to think sweetly of friends that are far away.'

title: Notes in England and Italy.

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Shall be this — from Qne, Margaret, countess dowager of Douglas, umquhile duchess dowager of Touraine, and lady of Longueville, Annandale, and Galloway, that James Stuart and the Gueldrian his wife may reign where they please, but I shall be queen on this side of tlie Nith, and woe to the man, be he lord or loon, who says me nay 1 "

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: Sir Patrick Gray longed to be at Thrave ; and his heart sickened with impatience during the tardy passage of the king's army through Ettrick Forest and Annandale,  the home of powerful and predatory Border clans, into Galloway j for malcontents and marauders were to be punished on every hand ; the growing corn-fields were swept by fire ; towers were stormed and castles dismantled,  by having their gates unhinged and their battlements  thrown down.

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: " You are a bold man to pass through the Johnstones of Annandale and the Borderland at this time."

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: "But who," asked the chancellor, "will be daring enough to bear such a message into the wilds of Galloway,  beyond the land of the Annandale thieves 1 "

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: Archibald Dunbar stormed the great castle of the earl of Ilailes, slew the inmates, and gave it up to the Douglases, while the moss-troopers of Annandale, lest their weapons should rust, kept all the western marches in hot water by their raids and devastations, which were seldom confined to their own border.

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: The doors of our residence are secured every night by Sir Alan Lauder, who keeps the keys with care, as if he were still in Thrave, and feared the thieves of Annandale.

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: " The Countess Margaret is heiress of Galloway, Wigton,  Balvenie, Ormond, and Annandale — a good slice of braid Scotland," replied MacLellan, in a bantering tone, as he hated the Douglases ; " James, umquhile only of Abercorn and Avondale, is a mighty lord ; so the most reverend father in God, Alexander — by divine permission bishop of Candida Casa (so run the pastorals to his pretty flock, the moss-troopers) — put a good round sum in gold nobles in his pouch, dozes away in his episcopal chair, and troubles not his mitred head about the matter ; for is not Abbot John of Tongland, the keeper of the earl's conscience, a Douglas ? By St. Paul, it is hardly wise or pleasant to call oneself by a diflerent surname on the other side of the Nith, and I have some thoughts of getting permission from the king-of-arms, to call myself

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: Then, to prevent the dismemberment of a territory so princely, and to preserve to the house of Douglas the Countess Margaret's portion, which comprehended Galloway,  Wigton, Balvenie, Ormond, and Annandale, on the promise of obtaining a papal dispensation, through the good offices of the abbot of Tongland, she consented to espouse Earl Jumes, that they might the better plot their

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Treason, in the daily oppression of the king's subjects, at the head of two thousand horsemen,  most of whom are outlawed moss-troopers and thieves of Annandale, who sorn on the king's lieges, and commit every outrage ; and this ye do, though the parliament held at Perth, in 1424, ordained that no man should travel abroad with more followers than he could maintain.

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: "I arrest you, William, duke of Touraine, earl of Douglas, lord of Annandale, Longueville, and Galloway, on charges of soul treason ; and you.

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: I would but pray you to execute justice on your vast estates of Galloway, Annandale,  and Balvenie with impartiality and gentleness ; and not to protect from the just vengeance of the king, our lord and master, those lawless barons who levy feudal war and destroy each other's towers, villages, and territories, and by so doing impoverish the realm and oppress the people.

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: In the same spirit the baillies wore shirts of mail under their velvet gowns, and the alarm increased rather than diminished when the Provost was heard to say to Sir Patrick Gray — " I am glad the King's Guard are in readiness, for the wild men of Galloway and those scurvy thieves and bully rooks of Annandale who follow the banner of Douglas, are certain to work mischief  in the town."

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: In his seventeenth year, William found himself master of all the princely heritage his warlike sire had left him, the earldom of Douglas, with the lordships of Both well, Annandale, and Liddesdale ; the county of Longoville, and the dukedom of Touraine, " the garden of France."

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: The first had the name of the most potent prince William, sixth earl of Douglas, third duke of Touraine, lord of Longoville, Galloway, Annandale, and Liddesdale, qui obit 237'd Nov.^ 1440, in his seventeenth year.

title: The history of a man.
author: Gilfillan, George
snippet: The public has not yet, however,  seen Aird fully — and that I account for on this theory — nor has it seen Carlyle either ; but it will one day see both : admire and tremble at the terrible Tom of Annandale, and admire and love the gentle and gifted Tom of the Eildon hills."

title: North of the Tweed, or, Lorance Langton: his life, incidents, and adventures in Scotland /
author: Crowberry, Daniel.
snippet: By an eminent Scotch historian it is recorded that, when the heroic John Bandolph and Archibald  Douglas, fighting under the banners of Bruce, assembled a force in Annandale and suddenly  attacked Baliol, who was then " feasting near Annan, they cut his guards in pieces, slov/ his brother, and chased him out of Scotland in such haste, that he escaped on horseback without time to clothe himself, or even to saddle his horse."

title: North of the Tweed, or, Lorance Langton: his life, incidents, and adventures in Scotland /
author: Crowberry, Daniel.
snippet: Upon the next day the buckskins were restored to their former hook within a sequestered vale in Annandale ; but still greater grace awaited them.

title: North of the Tweed, or, Lorance Langton: his life, incidents, and adventures in Scotland /
author: Crowberry, Daniel.
snippet: About the close of the twelfth century, when the kingdom of Scotland was convulsed by the civil wars, then fomented by the ambitious aims of Edward of England, and when the two rival lords of Annandale and Galloway— Bruce and Baliol— were contending for the Scottish crown, it happened that a noble youth and kinsman of the illustrious house of Douglas, named Belvany, fell into the hands of a company of English

title: Domestic details
author: Crossrig, David Hume
snippet: The Earle of Annandale opposed me in this, tho' under pretence of his setling with me, and in the mean time he obtained, by the means of Secretary Johnston, a gift of the Earle of Home's escheat, tho' this Earle is not owing him a farthing, under the pretence of debts owing by the Earle of Home's family to him or his predecessors ; and Kimmerghame having also obtained a gift under the King's hand, which he had kept latent a long time, whereupon the Earle of Annandale and Kimmergheme divided the Earle of Home's interest between  them.

title: Domestic details
author: Crossrig, David Hume
snippet: The Earle of Annandale opposed me in this, tho' under pretence of his setling with me, and in the mean time he obtained, by the means of Secretary Johnston, a gift of the Earle of Home's escheat, tho' this Earle is not owing him a farthing, under the pretence of debts owing by the Earle of Home's family to him or his predecessors ; and Kimmerghame having also obtained a gift under the King's hand, which he had kept latent a long time, whereupon the Earle of Annandale and Kimmergheme divided the Earle of Home's interest between  them.

title: The standard bearer,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Nor is this only a mock, as Hob would have made of it, saying with his queer smile, li Quintin,  what think ye o' a mission to the heathen divinity lads — to set the fire o' hell to their tails, even as Peden the Prophet bade Richie Cameron  do to the border thieves o' Annandale?

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: He was a handsome young man, of a good family in Annandale, who had not succeeded in business at Dumfries, and had been sent over by my uncle Provost  George Bell, of that town, as their agent and factor — as at that time they dealt pretty deep in the tobacco trade.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: Most unfortunately for me, I had made an appointment with Mr James Hogg, a probationer, and tutor to the four sons of Sir John Douglas of Kelhead, to ride ten or twelve miles with them on their way to Annandale ; and I had hardly become warm in bed when rap-rap he came to my door, and insisted on my getting up and fulfilling my promise.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: These were of select Annandale figures whom I had seen in my boyhood, and of whom, now that they were all vanished, I was glad to have, for the first time, some real knowledge as facts ; the outer simulacra, in all their equipments, being still so pathetically  vivid to me.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Sent for John, the first thing in the morning ; bade him get places in the night train for Annandale (my sister Mary's ; all kindness poor Mary, whom she always liked) ; "The Gill; we are not yet at the

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: The day after seeing her settled there, I made for Annandale, and my sister Mary's at the Gill.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Oh, was it not beautiful, all this that I have lost forever! And I was Thomas the Doubter, the unhoping ; till now the only half-believing, in myself and my priceless opulences ! At my return from Annandale, after " French Revolution," she so cheerily recounted to me all the good " items ;" item after item.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: The bride was Grace Welsh, of Capelgill (head of Moffat  Water in Annandale) ; her father an oi)ulent store-farmer up there, native of Nithsdale; her mother a Baillie from Biggar region,  already deceased.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Above two years before, from Kirkcaldy, I had forwarded to some magazine editor in Edinburgh what, perhaps, was a likelier little article (of descriptive tourist kind after a real tour by Yarrow country into Annandale), which also vanished without sign ; not much to my regret that first one, nor indeed very much the second either (a dull affair altogether, I could not but admit), and no third adventure  of the kind lay ahead for me.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Was found twice over in Cumberland ships, endeavoring to get to America, sailors universally refusing to list anchor till she were turned out ; did at length, most probably, smuggle herself through Liverpool or some other place to America ; at last vanished out of Annandale, and was no more talked of there.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Mrs. Oliphant, I think, relates that on getting back to London he was put under a kind of arrest by certain Angels or authorities  of his New "Irviugite" Church (just established in Newman  Street, Oxford Street), for disobeying regulations — perhaps in regard to those volunteer preachings in Annandale — and sat with great patience in some penitential place among them, dumb for about a week, till he had expiated that sin.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: It was our last of Irving in his native Annandale.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Early in April we got back to Annandale and Craigenputtoch.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Nowhere can I recollect of myself such pious musings, communings silent and siDontaneous with Fact and Nature, as in these poor Annandale localities.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: First, and most of all, that I would, renouncing ambitions, " fine openings," and the advice of all bystanders and friends, ivho didnH Mow ; go ho7ne to Annandale, were this work done; provide myself a place where I could ride, follow  regimen, and be free of noises (which were unendurable) till if possible I could recover a little health.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: White bonnet intensely vernacular, is the Annandale name for a false bidder merely appointed  to raise prices, works so for his five shillings at some poor little Annandale roup,* of standing crop or hypothecate cottage furniture, and the contrast and yet kinship between these little things and the Fonthill great one was ludicrous enough.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: White bonnet intensely vernacular, is the Annandale name for a false bidder merely appointed  to raise prices, works so for his five shillings at some poor little Annandale roup,* of standing crop or hypothecate cottage furniture, and the contrast and yet kinship between these little things and the Fonthill great one was ludicrous enough.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: '^ You will see now," he would say, " one day we two will shake hands across the brook, you as first in literature, I as first in divinity, and people will say, ' Both these fellows are from Annandale.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Irving was generally happy in those little Annandale "sunny islets" of his year; happier perhaps than ever elsewhere.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Those Nelsons I never saw again, but have heard once in late years that they never did anything, but continued ornamentally lounging with Liverpool as head - quarters ; which seemed to be something like the prophecy one might have gathered from those young aspects in the Annandale visit, had one been intent to scan them.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Irving's visits to Annandale, one or two every summer, while I spent summers (for cheapness' sake and health's sake) in' solitude at my father's there, were the sabbath times of the season to me ; by far the beautifuUest days, or rather the only beautiful I had! Unwearied kindness, all that tenderest anxious affection could do, was always mine from my incomparable mother, from my dear brothers, little clever active sisters, and from every one, brave father in his tacit grim way not at all excepted.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: At length reading one day in a public placard from the magistrates (of which there had been several) that on His Majesty's advent it was expected that everybody would be carefully well-dressed, " black coat and white duck trousers," if at all convenient, I grumbled to myself, "scandalous  flunkeys ! I, if I were changing my dress at all, should incline rather to be in white coat and black trousers ;" but resolved rather to quit the city altogether, and be absent and silent in such efflorescence  of the slunk eyisms, which I was — for a week or more in Annandale, at Kirkchrist with the Churches in Galloway ; ride to Lochinbrack "Well by Kenmore Lake, etc., how vivid still ! and found all comfortably rolled away at my return to Edinburgh.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: I as good as lost them on my leaving Annandale.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: The Graham Brothers house growing more and more prosperous and opulent in Philadelphia, resolved at last to have a branch in Glasgow (year 1814 or so) and despatched William thither, whose coming I dimly remember was heard of in Annandale by his triumphant  purchase for himself in see simple of the farm and hill of Buruswark, which happened to come into the market then.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: I remember her well, one of the amia- blest of old maids ; kind, true, modestly polite to the very heart ; and in such a curious style of polite culture ; Pennsylvanian Yankee  grafted on Annandale Scotch.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: William continued bachelor for life ; and this only sister returned ultimately to Annandale, and was William' s house-manager there.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: This I did not fail of, nor was it burdensome,  but otherwise, while near him in Annandale.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Frank was a notable kind of man, and one of the memorabilities to Irviug as well as me ; a most quizzing, merry, entertaining, guileless,  and unmalicious man ; with very considerable logic, reading, contemptuous observation and intelligence, much real tenderness too, when not obstructed, aud a mournfal true affection especially for the friends he had lost by death ! No mean impediment there any more (that was it), for Frank was very sensitive, easily moved to something of envy, and as if surprised when contempt was not possible ; easy banter was what he habitually dwelt in ; for the rest an honorable, bright, amiable man; alas, and his end was very tragic ! I have hardly seen a man with more opulence of conversation,  wit, fantastic bantering, ingenuity, and genial human sense of the ridiculous in men and things : Charles Buller, perhaps, but he was of far more refined, delicately managed, and less copious tone ; finer by nature, I should say, as well as by culture, and had nothing of the fine Annandale Rabelais turn which had grown up, partly of will and at length by industry as well, in poor Frank Dickson in the valley of Dryfe amid his little stock of books and rustic phenomena.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Annandale was not an irreligious  country, though Auuan itself (owing to a drunken clergyman  and the logical habits they cultivated) was more given to sceptical freethiukiug than other places.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Gavin voted the right way (Duke of Queensberry's way) and got for his two brothers each the lease of a snug Queensberry farm, which grew even the snugger  as dissolute old Queensberry developed himself more and more into a cynical egoist, sensualist, and hater of his next heir (the Buccleuch,  not a Douglas, but a Scott, who now holds both dukedoms), a story well known over Scotland, and of altogether lively interest in Annandale (where it meant entail - leases and large sums of money) during several years of my youth.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Let me here mention the reverent custom the old men had in Annandale of treating death even in their loosest thoughts.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: My father, I think, was of the second race of religious men in Annandale.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Annandale had long been a lawless Border country.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Happily there still existed in Annandale an influence of goodness, pure emblems of a religion.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: In the depth of winter I figure him with the others gathered round his father's hearth (now no longer so poor and desolate),  hunting (but now happily for amusement, not necessity), present here and there at some merry meetings and social doings, as poor Annandale, for poor yet God-created men, might then offer.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: He was born, I think, in the year 1757, at a place called Brownknowe,  a small farm not far from Burns wark Hill, in Annandale.

snippet: From England he took Northumberland, Westmoreland, Cumberland, and part ofDurham; from Scotland the counties of Berwick,Roxburgh, Peebles, Selkirk, Dumfries, and theStewartries of Kirkcudbright and Annandale.

snippet: His son Robert second was comrudo with David I. of Scotland, atthe Court of King Edward I. of England (1117), and on David succeeding tothe throne of Scotland m 1121, the King awarded Robert de Brus with theLordship of Annandale.

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: On the death of this baby Queen, violent competitionarose for the vacant throne of Scotland, between thedescendants of David, Earl of Huntingdon, third son ofDavid I., whose mother Maud, daughter of Waldeoff, Earl ofNorthumberland, by his wife Judith, who was a niece ofWilliam the Conqueror, John Balliol, Lord of Galloway;Robert Bruce, Lord of Annandale; and Sir John Hastings;all descendants of King David I. claimed the throne.
